fullProgramDescription: The Mathematics and Economics - Joint Major (B.S.) program is an interdisciplinary program offered by the Department of Mathematics. This program combines the study of mathematical theories and methods with the study of economic principles and practices. Students in this program develop a strong foundation in mathematical techniques, statistical analysis, and economic theory, preparing them for careers in fields such as finance, data analysis, and research.
shortProgramDescription: The Mathematics and Economics - Joint Major (B.S.) program provides students with a comprehensive education in both mathematics and economics, preparing them for a wide range of career opportunities.
classHighlights: The program requires students to complete a series of core courses in mathematics, including calculus (MATH20A-B-C-D), linear algebra (MATH18 or20F), and differential equations (MATH20D or21D).
Students also complete a set of core courses in economics, including microeconomics (ECON100A-B), macroeconomics (ECON101A-B), and econometrics (ECON120A-B-C).
In addition to these core courses, students choose from a range of electives in both mathematics and economics, allowing them to tailor their education to their interests and career goals.
Some of the elective courses in mathematics include probability and statistics (MATH180A-B-C), mathematical finance (MATH183), and mathematical modeling (MATH171A-B).

Elective courses in economics include advanced microeconomics (ECON110A-B-C), advanced macroeconomics (ECON111A-B-C), and specialized courses in areas such as international trade and economic development.
The program also requires students to complete a capstone course or other culminating experience, which helps them integrate their knowledge and skills and prepare for their future careers.
learningOutcomes: Apply mathematical techniques and methods to economic problems and theories.
Analyze and interpret economic data using statistical and econometric techniques.
Understand and apply microeconomic and macroeconomic theories.
Develop strong problem-solving and critical thinking skills.
Communicate complex ideas and results effectively.
Integrate knowledge from both mathematics and economics to tackle real-world problems.
additionalInformation: The Mathematics and Economics - Joint Major (B.S.) program is administered by the Department of Mathematics. Students are advised to consult with department advisors to plan their course of study and ensure they meet all program requirements.
